Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

The Program recommends an award of for the purchase of the following:

1) Network Server Upgrade/Replacement $6,500
2) NI VB-8034 (2 ea) $16,000
3) Fiber Optic Training, Supplies and Tester $12,000
Indirect Costs $5,180
Total $39,680

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome

In CY2017 University of Delaware R/V HUGH R. SHARP technical group received funding in the amount of $ 39,680 from National Science Foundation to advance and enhance the technical support provided by the ship support technicians group. A summary of each of these advancement/enhancement projects follows.

 

Network Sever Upgrade/Replacement

The duties provided by these two servers are: time services, DHCP, cell modem interface, Wi-Fi distribution, user network sharing, data backup and working science data copies with collected and historical data. Although data collection can accrue without the network, it would be basic data collection without off ship communications, science access, or redundant backup. This can severely cripple the level of science services required of our technical group. With the newly installed large capacity storage devices and a timeserver device, their workloads and functions are in the process of changing. The servers will remain the keystone for off ship communications, with cell phone and new satellite systems to come in the near future, but their function as timeserver and data storage have changed. They will not actually be the primary storage device, but will provide the controls for data storage and provide a scientific working copy of data. They will also provide an interface for the timeserver device, but will no longer control the distribution of these time services. Due to the network service changes and the increased reliance on all network functions, we duplicated these two machines so they can backup each other. The two network servers operate in parallel with each other, so that if one fails the other will automatically pick up the services to eliminate network downtime. This increase the reliability of the network science support systems aboard the ship, which, as learned from experience, is key to the proper operation of our science support services.

The proposed work included the purchase, setup, installation, and integration by our computer support company. This quote is included in the appendix. As with any installation, there will be a host of other components required (i.e. cables, rack slides). The network windows server software was installed under the existing University of Delaware site license. 

 

NI VB-8034 All in one-test instruments.

In today’s electronic test equipment market, it seems the choices are almost limitless. Our goal was to maximize our test requirements into an efficient and effective package of electronic test instrumentation. This package is portable and multifunction. The VB-8034 from National Instruments fit these requirements. It has multifunction with built in multi-meter, 2 channel oscilloscope, 8 I/O ports, and 3 power supplies. It is a digital unit with recording abilities. The VB-8034 can interface with a Windows PC or IPAD tablet, both with USB or wireless capabilities. This means the VB-8034 can be setup locally and controlled remotely thru the wireless connection. The specifications for the VB-8034 cover any of our current needs including troubleshooting our RESON 7125 Multibeam system. Since troubleshooting occurs both on the ship while at sea and in the shore support shop where instruments are left for repair, we purchased two support systems.

 

Fiber Optic Support Plan

As the requests for this fiber optic operational requirement grows, fewer of these groups will have this internal support ability. We have looked at bring outside support to cover these specialized requirements such as the Jason support group, but as the number of terminations and testing increase this quickly becomes cost prohibitive. Our technical services group is required to incorporate this ability into our support toolbox. Our group does have the parts for the mechanical terminating the cable and a very basic fiber optic splicing kit.

To meet this growing requirement we propose here a two-fold plan. First, our technical service group has attend fiber-optic training this consist of the follow goals:

             Fiber Optics Basics

             Fiber Optics Safety

            Fiber Optic Cable Testing Methods

            Fiber Optic Cable Termination Methods

This training was located at Marine Operations and two UNOLS fleet technicians attended. The goals provide the base knowledge to support the fiber optic cable aboard the R/V HUGH R. SHARP. Since these goals are now met, the group has purchased an advance starter set of fiber-optic tools. In addition to this tool set, a fiber-optic fusion splicer was submitted for NSF funding and accepted. This will be purchased in CY2018. All test components will be packaged for easy-shared use. As a continuation of the support, a fiber-optic termination will be considered as a standard termination for the ship’s existing fiber-optic cable.

We selected this direction to achieve the required operational goals of in-house fiber optic support in an efficient manner. This project should provide the required expansion for the technical support groups to support the fiber optical cable aboard our research ship.
